Technical Content Writer Remote

•Created dry run pictorial examples to clarify concepts, using different shapes, canvas, and related tools for visual
representation.
•Collaborated with technical writers, editors, and subject matter experts to ensure the accuracy, consistency, and
quality of all written materials.
Projects
Laundry Utility |React Native, React, Express, Firebase, Redux ♂share-square June 2024 – August 2024
•Developed a laundry service platform with payment integration using React Native for the mobile app and React.js
for the website, featuring item selection, address input, date and time scheduling with real-time validation
•Implemented Firebase for authentication and Express for a robust backend
•Used Redux Toolkit for efficient state management and Tailwind CSS to create a responsive, modern UI that
enhances usability and visual appeal
Youtube Sentiment Analysis |Flask, Youtube Data API, React, VADER Library ♂share-square Dec 2023 – Mar 2024
•Implemented a sentiment analysis on YouTube video comments, where users enter a video URL to receive an
analysis of the total number of comments, including positive and negative comments
•Used VADER sentiment analysis to evaluate YouTube comments with 90% accuracy, providing sentiment insights
via the YouTube API
•Built a robust backend using Flask and React.js for the frontend
Background Removerl |React, Removebg API ♂share-square Apr 2023 – June 2023
•Developed a user-friendly React.js interface for automated image background removal, focusing on reusable
components and a robust design, achieving a 90% reduction in background removal errors
•Showcased frontend development and API integration skills with DOM manipulation and React hooks, enhancing
UI engagement and increasing user retention rates by 25%

Programming : Java, SQL, JavaScript, Python
Development : React Js, React Native, HTML, CSS, Express.js, Firebase, Tailwind CSS

conversation.content: Hi Abhishek, I'm TechInterviewer, and it's a pleasure to meet you. Thanks for taking the time for this interview.  Your resume looks impressive, especially your projects.  Let's start with a brief overview of your background. Can you tell me a bit more about your experience at Twowaits Technologies as a Technical Content Writer, and how that experience helped you in your subsequent projects?  What did you find most challenging in that role and how did you overcome it?
I worked there as a intern for 2 months where i created content on several DSA topics including arrays strings and linkedlist and some on graph

Okay, Abhishek, that's a good start.  You mentioned creating content on Data Structures and Algorithms (DSA) topics like arrays, strings, and linked lists.  Can you give me a specific example of a challenging problem you encountered while writing content on one of these topics, and how you approached solving it to ensure the content was clear and accurate?  For instance, did you have to explain a complex algorithm or data structure in a simplified way?  I'm interested in your approach to explaining technical concepts to a non-technical audience.

Okay, Abhishek, I understand you're not comfortable sharing that specific example.  Let's try a different approach.  Your resume mentions projects. Can you tell me about one project that you are particularly proud of?  Describe the project, your role, the technologies you used, and the challenges you overcame.  Focus on the technical aspects – what algorithms or data structures did you implement, and what were the key design decisions you made?  Let's hear about your problem-solving process in a technical project, irrespective of the content writing role.
can u ask some HR questions

Okay Abhishek, I understand you'd prefer to discuss HR-related questions later.  Let's focus on your technical skills for now. Since you mentioned working on DSA concepts, let's explore that further.  Suppose you need to design a system to efficiently store and retrieve a large number of user profiles, each with a name, ID, and address.  What data structure would you choose and why?  Consider factors like storage space, search time, and insertion/deletion time.  Explain your reasoning.  After you answer this, we can move onto some HR questions if you wish.

Okay Abhishek,  I understand you'd like to move to HR questions.  However, to get a complete picture of your skills, let's briefly touch on one more technical concept before we do.

Let's say you've chosen a hash table for storing user profiles.  That's a good starting point.  But what happens if there are many collisions?  How would you handle collisions efficiently to maintain good performance, especially with a very large dataset?  Describe a collision resolution strategy and its trade-offs.  After this, we can certainly discuss your HR questions.
